name: Discocactus cephaliaciculosus
remarks: Buining and Brederoo (in Kakteen And. Sukk. 26(5): 97-100. 1975) proposed the name “Discocactus cephaliaciculosus”, provided a Latin description, and cited “Holotypus im Herbar Utrecht, Niederlande, unter Nr. 430/431” (referring to 2 collections; typification not achieved); therefore, the preceding name was invalid when published. Braun & Esteves, referenced to Buining and Brederoo, cited a single collection as the type, and validated the name. Nevertheless, Buining and Brederoo are the authors of the species name (see Shenzhen Code Art. 46 Exs. 22-23)

name: Tacinga armata
distribution: Paraíba (Brazil Northeast, Brazil, Southern America);Pernambuco (Brazil Northeast, Brazil, Southern America);
remarks: doi:10.11646/phytotaxa.490.3.2 The specific epithet is from the Latin armatus 'armed', in reference to the size of spines and their density on the plant (including flowers and fruits).

name: Tacinga × flammea
distribution: Minas Gerais (Brazil Southeast, Brazil, Southern America)
remarks: doi:10.11646/phytotaxa.490.3.2 The specific epithet is from the Latin flammeus 'flaming, flame-colored', in reference to the gradual outward color change (from orange to red) of the perianth segments, that gives it the appearance of a flaming torch.

name: Tacinga gladispina
locality: Morro do Chapéu. Próximo à Lagoa das Velhas, 924m
remarks: doi:10.11646/phytotaxa.490.3.2 The specific epithet combines Latin gladius 'sword' and spina 'spine', in reference to the spines shape and their position in the areoles (erect, mostly solitary spines sited centrally in the areoles, giving the impression of a sword).

name: Tacinga × grandiflora
locality: Município Boquira, road to São João, near the  communications tower, c. 1000 m
remarks: doi:10.25223/brad.n41.2023.a7 Etymology: named for its spectacular golden flowers, much longer than those of T. inamoena, twice as broad as those of T. funalis and thus, overall, the largest so far recorded in this genus, especially the perianth-segments.

name: Tacinga paiaia
locality: Morro do Chapéu. Próximo ao Areião, c. 600m da rodovia BA052, 927 m
remarks: doi:10.1600/036364423X17000842213542 Etymology: the specific epithet pays homage to the indigenous people (the Paiaiás) who inhabited the region of Sertão da Jacobina in northern Chapada Diamantina.
